Topic.Title: Sell AMZN and buy AAPL and start sleeping at night

Message.Msg: I have to agree with you. Apple has a compelling PE. Great cash flow & balance sheets. $140 billion in cash. It's a sound business. We can say the same for Oracle, Microsoft, and IBM. Amazon earned $82 million in the 1st quarter. Contrast that to the billions in profits made by the aforementioned companies. I see no reason to chase growth here. This story is repeated time and again, with people losing significant money once the market normalizes a company like Amazon. I prefer value investing in proven, profitable companies with great fundamentals. Better to make solid returns...as opposed to trying to get really high growth, only to be burned badly. It's just my 2 cents. Best of luck all.

Topic.Title: Techstrategy, how'd your leap puts do?

Message.Msg: Well. Thanks XGB. Notice the reverse AAPLtrage today. Any fund manager not exploiting it at double speed will be outperformed by the sane ones that do... Relative valuation is just too overextended (EV ratio is about 2 to 1, profits and true FCF closer to 10 to 1). Eventually, some intellectually honest analysts will do the homework that I've posted on this MB. Amazon's physical investments have not provided an advantaged cost structure and haven't solved the key issue -- th e last mile economics. Further, it has made Amazon MUCH more vulnerable to macro weakness. Look at the balance sheet compared to Q1 2012. Cash is about the same, but only because of $3B in LT debt issuance (and net of $1.5 after the office excuse). Days payable up by 10% or about $900MM. Accrued liabilities up by $1.8B. Clearly, none of the analysts have been entrepreneurs, because they would recognize the warnings signs if they had been... Amazon is a tail event waiting to happen. An oil price spike could make those Prime 2 day shipping commitments a back breaker. Regardless, the fundamental economic tradeoff embedded in the business model is simply not as compelling as it has been made out to be. And stacking loss leaders atop one another is a ponzi that will fail. I'll be posting more as I dissect the scam with this Q's numbers. I intend to rehash all of the Q3 and Q4 pumps, the reinvented analyst stories versus the critical fundamental analysis I've posted over the past yearand compare to actual earnings results (not self fulfilling price is truth works until it doesn't ponzi speculating, since that isn't what analysts are supposed to do). This has been a financial scam. It will get ugly as the year progresses. The public should get an some visibility into who orchestrated and who enabled the scam.
